subject: Re: [junit] Re: Class-level @Rule
msgSnippet: I think that it s likely easier to find agreement on what kind of new features could be added than on which of those might be added through an annotation
messageBody:
I think that it's likely easier to find agreement on what kind of new
features could be added than on which of those might be added through
an annotation containing the word "Rule", and which might be added in
a different way.

David Saff

On Wed, Apr 28, 2010 at 5:22 PM, yme0987654321 <yme0987654321@...> wrote:
>> On 28/04/10 00:36, yme0987654321 wrote:
>> > Hi Max,
>> >
>> > I guess my question is other than the syntactical sugar, what does a
>> > class level rule gain for you? I would expect it to be something more
>> > than a way of avoiding that kind of boilerplate.
>>
>> I just explained that in my previous reply. When the boilerplate that is
>> avoided is so excessive, the syntactic sugar itself becomes a valuable
>> feature.
>
> I really don't perceive that as excessive boilerplate. YMMV.
>
>> > As an example of the kind of thing I think a class rule would enable,
>> > is that it might allow the rule to dynamically pass values to the
>> > test class's constructor based on some dynamic criteria (say a souped
>> > up version of Parameterized)
>>
>> No. Test class instantiation occurs per-method, not per-class, thus
>> class-level is not where it can be changed.
>
> Test instantiation is yes, but I would expect a ClassRule to provide a hook into the instance generation process (although for the whole class, not each case at a time).
>
>> > or perhaps change the runner that will run the tests,
>>
>> No. The Runner is what invokes the rules, so rules can't change the runner.
>
> Just like the ExpectedException rule intercepts the Statement and replaces it with its own, a ClassRule can intercept the Runner and replace it with its own (possibly).
>
>> > Something that is not possible with an @BeforeClass
>> > or @AfterClass annotation.
>>
>> The ability to package a common class-level setup/teardown behaviour and
>> re-use it in many places is what rules provide over embedded
>> before/after methods. That's very useful by itself, and they don't have
>> to do anything more to justify their existence.
>
> Hmm, I guess we have to agree to disagree on that one.
